description: This course provides an understanding of the major materials issues for current and emerging energy technologies. It includes a classification of materials for energy applications involving generation, transmission and storage of electricity; current and future uses of fossil fuels, with emphasis on higher efficiency uses of fossil fuels and "all electric" applications (e.g. transportation and power generation) and new materials as technology enablers for future energy sources: nuclear, fuel cells, solar, wind.
name: ENERGY STORAGE & TECHNOL

values.comments:
This course provides an understanding of the major materials issues for current
and emerging energy technologies. It includes a classification of materials for energy
applications involving generation, transmission, and storage of electricity; current and
future uses of fossil fuels, with emphasis on higher efficiency uses of fossil fuels and "all
electric" applications (e.g. transportation and power generation) and new materials as
technology enablers for future energy sources: nuclear, fuel cells, solar, wind.
Many students stated that they thought the course material was extremely
interesting but a few students complained that the lecture notes were “unprofessional,”
“chaotic,” and “unoriginal.”
Many students appreciated his emails stating current topics in energy storage
technology. Some students complained that he was very involved in his research and did
not have much time to see students outside of class.
This class is meant for seniors or graduate students in the materials science
engineering department. However, this class can be taken by any engineer and was
“highly recommended to anyone wanting a good overview of energy technology.”
Only 7 students submitted written reviews for this class.
